III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of Staff
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
1

perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 02/25/23, youth had cut herself from her foot up to her
stomach and completely up her leg. Youth was bleeding when she
was found.
Investigation This complaint was received on 03/09/2023 and investigated in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist.
The complainant was anonymous and contact information was not
available for following up.
I interviewed Foster Care Specialist at the facility on 03/10/2023,
in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist. She reported a safety
plan developed by the clinical team was implemented because of
the incident on 02/25/2023. She provided a copy of the plan dated
03/01/2023. Foster Care Specialist did not express any concerns
regarding staff not supervising Youth A.
I interviewed Consumer Rights Officer at the facility on 03/10/2023
in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist. He reported Youth A
was hospitalized on 02/25/2023 due to self-harming and taking
medication that she had been cheeking. Consumer Rights Officer
said there were three staff members on the wing when this
incident occurred, Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3. He said Staff 1 was
onsite, but Staff 2 off, and Staff 3 is no longer employed at the
facility.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 03/10/2023, in collaboration
with the DHHS Specialist. Youth A has been at the facility since
12/15/2022. She reported on 02/25/2023, she removed a piece of
tile from the bathroom wall and used it to self-harm by scratching
her legs. She did this in her bedroom. She said staff were on the
unit and she was in her room for approximately 5 minutes. She
said staff immediately responded by cleaning her cuts and putting
ointment on her wounds. Youth A told staff that she also took 6
pills that she been hiding in her bedroom. She said she had been
collecting the pills by hiding them in her mouth and not swallowing
her pills. Youth A said staff immediately called 911 and while
waiting for the ambulance staff were putting cold water on her
forehand because she felt like she was going to pass out. Youth A
said after she was discharged from the hospital she was watched
2

by staff and was seen by her therapist and doctor. Youth A said
now she is required to sit with staff for 30 minutes after she takes
her medication to ensure that she swallows her medication and is
not hiding it in her mouth. She expressed no concerns regarding
staff supervision or the facility.
I interviewed Youth B at the facility on 03/10/2023, in collaboration
with the DHHS Specialist. Youth B reported feeling safe and
getting enough to eat. She said there is always a staff member on
the wing. She reported no concerns regarding staff supervision.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 03/10/2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Specialist. Staff 1 is a Direct Care Worker and has
been working at the facility for 2 years. Staff 1 was working on the
wing on 02/25/2023 and recalls the incident involving Youth A.
Staff 1 was sitting at the table with two other residents and she
saw Youth A come out of her room. She said Staff 1 had to
immediately remove the other two residents out of the wing, while
staff attended to Youth A. She said there were two other staff
members on the wing taking care of Youth A and she saw the
nurse and social worker come on the wing to assist as well.
I interviewed Therapist at the facility on 03/10/2023, in
collaboration with DHHS Specialist. Therapist reported Youth A
had not reported feeling depressed or having thoughts about self-
harm, because Youth A is usually very “bubbly” and outgoing.
Therapist said several staff were on the wing supervising Youth A
when Youth A went to her room and self-harmed.
I interviewed Nurse at the facility on 03/10/2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Specialist. Nurse reported receiving a call on
02/25/2023 from staff in reference to Youth A self-harming and
having cuts on her thigh area. She instructed staff to clean the
cuts and remove any items used to self-harm from the youth’s
room. She said staff were supervising the unit when the youth
self-harmed in her room.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the facility on 03/28/2023. Staff 2 is a Team
Leader and has been working at the facility for two years. Staff 2
is also a certified medical assistant. She said Youth A had gone to
her room and used a broken bathroom tile to self-harm. She said
staff immediately responded by attending to Youth A’s injury, and
by contacting the nurse, therapist, and doctor who instructed them
to contact 911. She said staff were on the unit and supervising
when Youth A self-harmed.
3

On 04/06/2023 a Predisposition case conference held with DHHS
Specialist and managers. No findings.
Documents reviewed:
Incident reported dated 02/25/2023, Staff 3. Youth A was in her
room, she stepped out and asked staff for help, staff observed cut
marks on both legs, staff contacted nurse and therapist. Staff
cleaned the wounds on Youth A’s leg, Youth A began to cry
uncontrollably and, in a panic, said she had taking several of her
medication that she had been hiding in her bedroom. Staff were
instructed to contact 911.
Analysis The facility is complaint with the rule as there is insufficient
evidence that staff were not supervising the youth. Youth reported
staff were on the unit when Youth A went to the bathroom and
removed a tile from the wall, went to her room for about five
minutes, and used the tile to self-harm.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
(c) Documentation of medical care and maintenance of health
records.
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff did not call 911 in response to youth’s emergency. About an
hour later, 911 was called and youth was then transported to the
hospital. Youth had also been collecting her medication and had
taken approximately 7-8 of unknown pills that she had been
collecting and began having a seizure. Youth has since returned
to the facility. Youth was supposed to be monitored 24/7 but she
only was monitored like for two days before she was released
back to normal monitoring.
Investigation Consumer Rights Officer reported Youth A had been cheeking her
medication. A room search was conducted on 02/25/2023 and one
pill was found on top of her dresser in the gap between the
dresser and wall. Blood work was completed on Youth A when
she was hospitalized, and levels were in the normal range. Youth
4

A was moved to a different wing and her room does not have a
dresser.
Youth A said staff immediately called 911 and while waiting for the
ambulance staff were putting cold water on her forehand because
she felt like she was going to pass out. Youth A said she told staff
that she took 6 pills that she been hiding in her bedroom. She said
she had been collecting the pills by hiding them in her mouth and
not swallowing her pills. Youth A said some staff check her mouth
after she takes her medication, and some staff don’t. Youth A said
now she is required to sit with staff for 30 minutes after she takes
her medication to ensure that she swallows her medication and is
not hiding in her mouth. Youth A said she has been meeting with
her therapist weekly and there is always a staff member
supervising on her wing. She expressed no concerns regarding
staff supervision or the facility.
Youth B reported she takes medication and gets her medication
daily. She said staff give her medication and check her mouth to
make sure she swallowed the medication. She denied hiding
medication in her mouth.
Staff 1 reported staff immediately acted and contacted the nurse
and doctor and were instructed to call 911. Youth A was taken to
the hospital and when she returned, she was initially on a 1:1 staff
ratio, which requires staff to be always within an arm's length of
the resident. Youth A was moved off the 1:1 after two days when
she was assessed by the psychiatrist. Staff 1 stated that the
procedure for the medication dispensing is that the youth is given
the medication, staff watch the youth take the medication, then the
staff will check the youth’s mouth to ensure the youth swallowed
the medication. Staff 1 said since Youth A’s incident, staff will
watch her take her medications, check her mouth, and Youth A
must be observed for 30 minutes to make sure she has swallowed
the medication.
Therapist reported when a youth self-harms, the staff notify the
supervisor, the clinical manager, nurse, therapist, and psychiatrist.
She reported she was immediately notified, and staff were
instructed to call 911. She said Youth A was taken to the hospital
on 02/25/2023 and when she was discharged, she was placed on
1:1 staff ratio until she was assessed by the psychiatrist two days
later. Youth A was then assessed by the psychiatrist and
approved for the step-down supervision. She said a safety and
behavior plan was developed with the clinical team and the Foster
Care Specialist prior to Youth A being approved for the step-down
5

supervision. She is also doing random check-ins with Youth A
outside of her scheduled therapy sessions to ensure she is safe
and not having thoughts about self-harm.
Nurse reported she was notified about Youth A self-harming and
was informed that staff also notified the doctor, who instructed
staff to contact 911 when Youth A reported she had also taken
medication. Nurse reported Youth A does not have a history
seizure. She reviewed Youth A’s medical report after she was
discharged from the hospital, and said the report indicated Youth
A’s lab tests and blood level were all in the normal range, so she
was not sure that Youth A took any medication. Nurse said staff
did clear Youth A’s room and found one pill hidden on top of a
shelf in a wedge between the wall and shelf. Youth A has since
been moved to a different room and there is no shelf in the room.
Youth A has also been placed on a safety plan, which staff must
supervise Youth A for 30 minutes after she takes her medication.
Staff 2 said staff immediately responded by attending to Youth A’s
injury, which were superficial cuts, so initially they were going to
transport Youth A to the hospital. When Youth A reported she had
also taken medication, the doctor instructed them to contact 911.
She said 911 was called immediately and the EMS arrived within
30 minutes of them calling 911. While they were waiting for the
EMS unit to arrive, she was using a wet towel on Youth A
forehead. Staff 2 said Youth A felt warm and appeared lethargic,
so staff initially thought Youth A was having a seizure. Once Youth
A was placed in the ambulance Youth A seemed fine and
appeared in good spirits. Staff 2 went with Youth A to the hospital
and was informed that Youth A did not have a seizure.
A follow up interview was conducted with Youth A at the facility on
04/06/2023. Youth A admitted that she managed to save her
medication that she took it on 02/25/2023 by hiding them in her
mouth. She said staff did check her mouth, but she used her
tongue to move the pill between her lower cheek and gums so
staff could not see the pill. Youth A denied currently feeling
suicidal or “cheeking” her medication.
Documents reviewed:
• Incident reported dated 02/25/2023, Staff 3. Youth A was in her
room, she stepped out and asked staff for help, staff observed cut
marks on both legs, staff contacted nurse and therapist. Staff
cleaned the wounds on Youth A’s leg, Youth A began to cry
uncontrollably and, in a panic, said she had taking several of her
medication that she had been hiding in her bedroom. Staff were
6

instructed to contact 911.
• Facility’s Emergency Medical Care Policy: If a client becomes
seriously ill or is injured, the shift Supervisor and or Team Leader
must take prompt steps to obtain medical care for the client. Life-
threatening illness/injury. The supervisor must immediately call
911 if a client appears to have a life-threatening or critical illness
or injury.
• Facility’s Medication Administration Policy: Carefully watch the
client take oral medication and verify all medications have been
swallowed by checking the mouth for any retained medication.
• Hospital Discharge papers for Youth A dated 02/25/2023.
Urinalysis and drug test were negative. CT scan normal and no
indication of youth having seizures.
• Youth A’s safety plan dated 03/01/2023.
b. Youth A is on 100% supervision upon her return from Hospital.
100% supervision means she is 1:1 on the wing.
c. Once she off 100 after the first 24 hours Youth A is to be placed
on 15-minute self-harm observations. Youth A room is to remain
free of items.
c. Medications must be brought and administered to Youth A on
the unit. Youth A is to be placed on medication observation
following medication passing, which entails the following.
i. medications must be taken with water and for the first 30
minutes after her medication is taken observation must be
completed in 5-minute intervals
ii. observation documentation must be completed in 5- minute
increments.
iii. Youth A cannot enter her room or bathroom during
this 30-minute medication observation period.
• Youth A’s case note dated 03/01/2023 authored by: Therapist 1.
Utilized TF-CBT, strengths-based perspective, encouragement,
clarification, reframing, affirmations, set limits. Youth A was
removed from 100% observation. Youth A has been placed on 15-
minute observation for Self-Harm and a safety plan. Medication
compliance and impulsivity management were explored.
Psychiatrist was present.
.
Analysis The facility is compliant with the rules as the documentation
provided by the facility, interviews with Staff, Nurse, Therapist,
and Youth A confirmed staff responded appropriately, contacted
911, dispensed medication according to their policy, and followed
Youth A’s treatment plan. Medical report indicated Youth A’s lab
tests and blood level were all in the normal range, so it could not
be determined that Youth A had taken medication that she
claimed she was “cheeking” and hiding in her bedroom. The
therapist reported Youth A was initially put 100% 1:1 observation
7

for the two days post-discharge, and then Youth A was evaluated
by the psychiatrist and approved for the step-down supervision.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
